abstract: <jats:p>A long tradition of separate Nearctic and Palaearctic taxonomic studies of the diverse aleocharine rove beetles (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae) has obscured the recognition of Holarctic species and detection of adventive species in both regions. Recently, integrated study of the two regions through detailed morphological comparisons and development of an authoritatively identified DNA barcode reference library has revealed the degree to which these two aleocharine faunas are interconnected, both naturally and through human activity. Here this approach is adopted to recognize new species, reveal Holarctic species, and recognize adventive species in both North America and Europe. The following new species are described: <jats:italic>Isoglossa triangularis</jats:italic> Klimaszewski, Brunke &amp; Pentinsaari, <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> from British Columbia; <jats:italic>Gnypeta impressicollis</jats:italic> Klimaszewski, Brunke &amp; Pentinsaari, <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, from Ontario, Maryland and North Carolina; <jats:italic>Aloconota pseudogregaria</jats:italic> Klimaszewski, Brunke &amp; Pentinsaari, <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold>, from Ontario and Virginia; and <jats:italic>Philhygra pseudolaevicollis</jats:italic> Klimaszewski, Brunke &amp; Pentinsaari, <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> from eastern Canada. <jats:italic>Dasygnypeta velata</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Philhygra angusticauda</jats:italic> are revealed to be Holarctic species, resulting in the following synonymies: <jats:italic>Dasygnypeta velata</jats:italic> (Erichson, 1839) = <jats:italic>Gnypeta minuta</jats:italic> Klimaszewski &amp; Webster, 2008, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> and <jats:italic>Philhygra angusticauda</jats:italic> (Bernhauer, 1909) = Atheta (Philhygra) pinegensis Muona, 1983, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> The Nearctic species <jats:italic>Hylota ochracea</jats:italic> (and genus <jats:italic>Hylota</jats:italic>), <jats:italic>Thecturota tenuissima</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Trichiusa robustula</jats:italic> are newly reported from the Palaearctic region as adventive, resulting in the following synonymies: <jats:italic>Hylota ochracea</jats:italic> Casey, 1906 = Stichoglossa (Dexiogyia) forticornis Strand, 1939, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold>; <jats:italic>Thecturota tenuissima</jats:italic> Casey, 1893 = <jats:italic>Atheta marchii</jats:italic> Dodero, 1922, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold>; and <jats:italic>Trichiusa robustula</jats:italic> Casey, 1893 = <jats:italic>T. immigrata</jats:italic> Lohse, 1984, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> The Palaearctic species <jats:italic>Amarochara forticornis</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Anomognathus cuspidatus</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Oligota pumilio</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Parocyusa rubicunda</jats:italic> are newly confirmed from the Nearctic region as adventive, resulting in the following synonymies: <jats:italic>Parocyusa rubicunda</jats:italic> (Erichson, 1837) = <jats:italic>Chilopora americana</jats:italic> Casey, 1906, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> and <jats:italic>Anomognathus cuspidatus</jats:italic> (Erichson, 1839) = <jats:italic>Thectura americana</jats:italic> Casey, 1893, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> The genus <jats:italic>Dasygnypeta</jats:italic>, <jats:bold>sensu nov.</jats:bold> is newly reported from North America, <jats:italic>Paradilacra</jats:italic> is newly reported from eastern North America, and <jats:italic>Haploglossa</jats:italic> is newly reported from Canada, resulting in the following synonymy: <jats:italic>Paradilacra densissima</jats:italic> (Bernhauer, 1909) = <jats:italic>Gnypeta saccharina</jats:italic> Klimaszewski &amp; Webster, 2008, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> Native <jats:italic>Cyphea wallisi</jats:italic> is newly reported from across Canada and <jats:italic>C. curtula</jats:italic> is removed from the Nearctic fauna. The status of both <jats:italic>Gyrophaena affinis</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Homalota plana</jats:italic> is uncertain but these species are no longer considered to be adventive in North America. Three new combinations are proposed: <jats:italic>Dasygnypeta baranowskii</jats:italic> (Klimaszewski, 2020) and <jats:italic>D. nigrella</jats:italic> (LeConte, 1863) (both from <jats:italic>Gnypeta</jats:italic>) and <jats:italic>Mocyta scopula</jats:italic> (Casey, 1893) (from <jats:italic>Acrotona</jats:italic>). <jats:italic>Dolosota</jats:italic> Casey, 1910, <jats:bold>syn. nov.</jats:bold> (type species <jats:italic>Eurypronota scopula</jats:italic> Casey), currently a subgenus of <jats:italic>Acrotona</jats:italic>, is therefore synonymized with <jats:italic>Mocyta</jats:italic> Mulsant &amp; Rey, 1874. Additionally, four new Canadian records and 18 new provincial and state records are reported.</jats:p>
title: Integrative taxonomy of Nearctic and Palaearctic Aleocharinae: new species, synonymies, and records (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae)
